comment.author: 10646517@N00
comment._content: This woman's dress and hair style and the composition of the portrait look like 1860s to me. Is there a basis for the "ca. 1875" date?

comment.author: 8421531@N04
comment._content: The dog looks rather like an Irish Wolfhound.  The massive size fits too.

comment.author: 32008531@N08
comment._content: No doubt, a breathtaking portrait. The proportions of the framing and the solid black background enhance the couple's transcendence. The dog leans with such calmness on the lady's lap and she holds his head between her hands in such a way, that I feel they are true companions.

comment.author: 25790743@N03
comment._content: She looks so worried. So concerned. Not happy at all. But it is the negative space that make this so powerful to me. Lovely

comment.author: 63121350@N00
comment._content:
Jeason, I've had the same contention about the dating of several of these Eastman photos...the fashion doesn't correspond with the date.

Then again, that may be when they ran a print off an older negative.  That could be a reasonable explanation.

comment.author: 29523042@N03
comment._content: Slightly edited version-

comment.author: 30272516@N08
comment._content: i love the vintage...but this girl looks so creepy, it gives it kind of a frightening mood, i like it

comment.author: 14362607@N02
comment._content:
I disagree that she is creepy.  When this was taken people didn't smile when photographs were taken.  In addition, the dog was included in the photo. This is not something you see often. Photographs typically were more formal.  

The fact that she included the dog indicates to me that he/she was a special part of her life.  Note that the dog has his head on her lap, and her hands are loving touching him.  It is a sign of trust, tenderness and love. This photo tells more that what is seen at first glance.  You must take time to read it.

comment.author: 28436664@N04
comment._content: I agree with jaeson47, the date is off. The clothes are not 1875, early 60s is a much better guess. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1860s_in_fashion vs. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1870s_in_fashion totally different.

comment.author: 25516099@N07
comment._content: Glass Countertops says: just AMAZING!

comment.author: 64838194@N02
comment._content: I agree with marcyphotos that she looks concerned or upset. But we need to remember what was involved with photographing back then--metal rods up the back, incredibly long set up and exposure times. It's amazing anyone went through it. I did and was yelling at the photographer!
